tool.name: TRIC
tool.description: integrates information from all available runs via a graph-based alignment strategy
tool.command:
feature_alignment.py --in #echo '" "'.join([ str($file) for $file in $inputs ]) --out $out --out_matrix out_matrix.tsv --out_ids $out_ids --file_format $iformat --method $method_sel.method --realign_method $realign_method #if $max_rt_diff: --max_rt_diff $max_rt_diff #end if #if $fdr_sel == "opt_target_fdr": --target_fdr $fdr_sel.target_fdr #else: --fdr_cutoff $fdr_sel.fdr_cutoff #end if --max_fdr_quality $max_fdr_quality #if $method_sel.method == "LocalMST" or $method_sel.method == "LocalMSTAllCluster": --mst:useRTCorrection $method_sel.mst_useRTCorrection --mst:Stdev_multiplier $method_sel.mst_Stdev_multiplier --mst:useLocalStdev $method_sel.mst_useLocalStdev #end if #if $further_params.disable_isotopic_grouping == "False": --disable_isotopic_grouping $further_params.disable_isotopic_grouping #end if #if $further_params.use_dscore_filter == "True": --use_dscore_filter $further_params.use_dscore_filter --dscore_cutoff $further_params.dscore_cutoff #end if --nr_high_conf_exp $further_params.nr_high_conf_exp --readmethod $further_params.readmethod ## --tmpdir --alignment_score $further_params.alignment_score && cat out_matrix.tsv > $out_matrix
## Add TRIC requantification later. See https://github.com/msproteomicstools/msproteomicstools/blob/master/TRIC-README.md

param.name: inputs
param.label: Output files containing all peakgroups from OpenSWATH (using either mProphet or pyProphet) or Peakview.

param.name: iformat
param.label: Which input file format is used

param.name: method
param.label: Which method to use for the clustering
param.help: Note that the MST options will perform a local, MST guided alignment while the other options will use a reference-guided alignment. The global option will also move peaks which are below the selected FDR threshold. (--method)

param.name: realign_method
param.label: How to re-align runs in retention time
param.option: Use only deltaiRT (diRT) from the input file
Perform a linear regression using best peakgroups
Use Robust locally weighted regression (lowess smoother)
Use Python native spline from scikits.datasmooth (slow!)
Perform a spline fit using R
Perform a spline fit using R
Use Multivariate Adaptive Regression Splines using py-earth

param.name: max_rt_diff
param.label: Maximal difference in RT for two aligned features

param.name: fdr
param.label: Which FDR method should be used?

param.name: target_fdr
param.label: Target FDR
param.help: Refers to the desired FDR on assay level. (--target_fdr)

param.name: fdr_cutoff
param.label: Seeding score cutoff
param.help: A fixed m-score cutoff which does not take into account the number of runs (use target_fdr instead).

param.name: max_fdr_quality
param.label: Extension score cutoff
param.help: During the extension phase of the algorithm, peakgroups of this quality will still be considered for alignment (in FDR) - it is possible to give a range in the format lower,higher+stepsize,stepsize - e.g. 0,0.31,0.01 (-1 will set it to fdr_cutoff) (--max_fdr_quality)

param.name: disable_isotopic_grouping
param.label: Disable grouping of isotopic variants
param.help: Disable grouping of isotopic variants by peptide_group_label, thus disabling matching of isotopic variants of the same peptide across channels. If turned off, each isotopic channel will be matched independently of the other. If enabled, the more certain identification will be used to infer the location of the peak in the other channel.

param.name: use_dscore_filter
param.label: Enable the filter by d score (this is mainly for speedup)

param.name: dscore_cutoff
param.label: d score cut-off
param.help: Quality cutoff to still consider a feature for alignment using the d_score: everything below this d-score is discarded (this is mainly for speedup).

param.name: nr_high_conf_exp
param.label: Number of experiments with high confidence
param.help: Number of experiments in which the peptide needs to be identified with high confidence (e.g. above fdr_curoff).

param.name: readmethod
param.label: Read full or minimal transition groups

param.name: alignment_score
param.label: Alignment score
param.help: Minimal score needed for a feature to be considered for alignment between runs (e.g. score needed to be considered an 'anchor point' for pairwise alignment).

tool.help:
**What it does**
TRIC uses a graph-based alignment strategy based on non-linear retention time correction to integrate information from all available runs. The input consists of a set of csv files derived from a targeted proteomics experiment generated by OpenSWATH (using either mProphet or pyProphet) or generated by Peakview.
There are two basic running modes available. The first one uses a reference-based alignment where a single run is chosen as a reference and all other runs are aligned to it. This is a useful choice for a small number of runs that are chromatographically similar. The second mode generates a guidance tree based on chromatographic similarity of the input runs and uses this tree to align the targeted proteomics runs (the nodes in the tree are runs and the edges are pairwise alignments). Generally this mode is better for a large number of runs or for chromatographically dissimilar samples.
TRIC is part of msproteomicstools. For additional help please visit the `TRIC documentation <https://github.com/msproteomicstools/msproteomicstools/blob/master/TRIC-README.md>`_
